description.short: Measures the degree to which organizations unconsciously project their disowned aggressive, destructive, or threatening aspects onto external cybersecurity threats while idealizing internal employees and trusted partners
description.context: Shadow projection occurs when organizations unconsciously focus all security concerns on external 'bad actors' while idealizing internal employees and trusted partners as inherently safe. This psychological blind spot leads to systematic underinvestment in insider threat detection and creates vulnerabilities that sophisticated attackers routinely exploit.
description.impact: Organizations exhibiting strong shadow projection spend heavily on perimeter defenses while remaining vulnerable to social engineering, insider threats, and supply chain compromises. Historical incidents include the Aldrich Ames CIA case, Edward Snowden revelations, and numerous corporate data breaches involving exploitation of insider access.
description.psychological_basis: Jung (1969) identified the shadow as containing both personal and collective unconscious contents that the ego refuses to acknowledge. Klein's (1946) work on splitting demonstrates how anxiety-provoking objects are divided into 'all good' and 'all bad' categories. Bion's (1961) research shows how groups project internal anxieties onto external threats (fight-flight assumption), leading to aggressive defensive postures that neglect internal vulnerabilities.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 √ó Quick_Assessment + w2 √ó Conversation_Depth + w3 √ó Red_Flags) √ó Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Balanced Threat Recognition
green.description: Organization maintains balanced investment in both internal and external threat detection, with 30%+ of security budget allocated to insider threat programs. Equal priority given to investigating internal and external threats. Regular access reviews with documented findings. Formal vendor security assessment with ongoing monitoring.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - External Focus
yellow.description: Organization shows moderate external focus with 15-30% of security budget for insider threats. Some delay in investigating internal versus external alerts. Semi-annual access reviews with limited follow-up. Basic vendor security requirements without ongoing monitoring.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Heavy External Projection
red.description: Organization exhibits heavy shadow projection with less than 15% of security budget allocated to insider threat detection. Significant delays or lower priority for internal threat investigation. Annual or ad-hoc access reviews. Minimal vendor security oversight. Post-incident analysis focuses primarily on external attacker sophistication.

linguistic_analysis.description: Shadow content detection through semantic opposition using word embeddings
linguistic_analysis.interpretation: Higher values indicate stronger linguistic projection of organizational shadow onto external threats

behavioral_pattern.description: Measures ratio of external attribution to total incidents multiplied by complementarity of projected traits
behavioral_pattern.interpretation: Higher ratios indicate systematic externalization of responsibility for security incidents

shadow_projection_index.description: Complementary trait analysis measuring divergence between internal and external trait assessments

temporal_decay.description: Exponential smoothing with 72-168 hour time constant for unconscious pattern persistence

detection_threshold.formula: R_8.1(t) = 1 if SP_i(t) > 0.7 AND blame_ratio > 0.8, else 0
detection_threshold.interpretation: Binary detection triggers when shadow projection index exceeds 0.7 and external blame attribution exceeds 80%

blame_ratio.query: SELECT (COUNT(attribution='external') / COUNT(*)) FROM incidents WHERE time_window='12_months'

resource_balance.query: SELECT (SUM(insider_budget) / SUM(total_security_budget)) FROM budget WHERE fiscal_year=current

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Security Budget Allocation: Internal vs. External Threats
items.question: What percentage of your annual cybersecurity budget is specifically allocated to insider threat detection, employee behavior monitoring, and privileged access oversight versus external threat prevention (firewalls, endpoint protection, threat intelligence)?

options.label: 30% or more allocated to insider threat programs, behavioral analytics, and privileged access management
15-30% allocated to insider threat detection and internal monitoring
Less than 15% allocated to insider threat programs, with majority focused on perimeter defense

items.evidence_required: Detailed cybersecurity budget breakdown showing insider threat tool spending, UBA platform costs, PAM licensing

items.title: Alert Investigation Priority: Internal vs. External
items.question: When your security team receives alerts, how quickly do you typically investigate suspicious activity from internal users compared to external threats?

options.label: Internal and external alerts receive equal investigation priority with similar response times
Internal alerts investigated but with lower priority or longer response time than external threats
Internal alerts deprioritized or investigated only after external threats are addressed

items.evidence_required: Recent example showing investigation timeline for internal alert versus external alert on same day, SIEM alert prioritization configuration

items.title: Privileged Access Review Frequency and Rigor
items.question: How often do you conduct comprehensive reviews of employee access rights, and what's your process for investigating employees who access unusual systems or data?

options.label: Quarterly comprehensive access reviews with documented findings and investigation of anomalous access patterns
Semi-annual access reviews with limited follow-up on unusual access patterns
Annual or ad-hoc access reviews with minimal documentation of findings or investigation of anomalies

items.evidence_required: Last access review report with findings, example of investigation triggered by unusual internal access

items.title: Trusted Vendor and Partner Security Oversight
items.question: What specific security controls do you require from trusted vendors and business partners, and how do you monitor their access to your systems?

options.label: Formal vendor security assessment program with ongoing monitoring, network segmentation, and regular security reviews
Basic vendor security requirements during onboarding but limited ongoing monitoring
Minimal vendor security oversight beyond contractual agreements, vendors treated as trusted extensions of organization

items.evidence_required: Vendor security assessment procedure, example of vendor access monitoring, network segmentation for vendor connections

items.title: Post-Incident Analysis Focus: Internal vs. External Factors
items.question: When you experience a security incident, what percentage of your investigation focuses on internal factors (employee behavior, process failures, access controls) versus external attacker capabilities?

options.label: Post-incident analysis consistently examines both internal factors and external attacker methods with balanced investigation
Post-incident analysis occasionally considers internal factors but emphasizes external attacker sophistication
Post-incident analysis focuses primarily on external attacker capabilities with minimal examination of internal vulnerabilities

items.evidence_required: Last major incident analysis report showing investigation scope, root cause analysis including internal factors

items.title: Security Awareness Training Content Balance
items.question: What percentage of your security training and communications focuses on insider threats, social engineering targeting employees, and internal security responsibilities versus external threats like hackers and malware?

options.label: 40% or more of security training addresses insider risks, employee responsibilities, and internal threat scenarios
20-40% of security training addresses internal risks and employee security responsibilities
Less than 20% of security training addresses insider risks, with majority focused on external threats

items.evidence_required: Security awareness training curriculum, phishing simulation program including insider impersonation scenarios
items.soc_mapping: Training completion data categorized by internal vs external threat content

items.title: Threat Intelligence Source Balance
items.question: What sources do you use for threat intelligence, and how much of your threat intelligence specifically addresses insider threats, social engineering techniques, and supply chain risks versus external attack methods?

options.label: Threat intelligence includes dedicated insider threat indicators, social engineering campaigns, and supply chain risk sources
Limited insider threat intelligence sources supplementing primary external threat feeds
Threat intelligence sources focus almost exclusively on external threats, malware signatures, and attack techniques

items.evidence_required: List of threat intelligence subscriptions and feeds, examples of insider threat intelligence consumed
items.soc_mapping: Threat intelligence source categorization in SIEM

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: When you think about cybersecurity threats to your organization, what comes to mind first - and what percentage of your security concerns involve external attackers versus internal risks like employees, vendors, or privileged access abuse?

scoring_guidance.green: Spontaneously mentions both internal and external threats with realistic assessment of insider risks, can quantify balanced concern
scoring_guidance.yellow: Primarily mentions external threats but acknowledges insider risks when prompted, vague about actual balance
scoring_guidance.red: Exclusively focuses on external threats (hackers, nation-states, criminals) with minimal consideration of insider vulnerabilities

followups.text: Tell me about the last security incident you experienced - how much of the investigation focused on understanding internal factors versus characterizing the external attacker?
When you communicate about security threats to your organization or board, what language and examples do you typically use?

items.text: Walk me through how your security budget is allocated. What percentage goes toward monitoring and detecting threats from within your organization versus preventing external intrusions?

scoring_guidance.green: Can provide specific percentages showing 25%+ allocation to insider threat, explains rationale based on risk assessment
scoring_guidance.yellow: General sense of budget allocation but can't provide specific percentages, acknowledges potential imbalance
scoring_guidance.red: Admits vast majority spent on perimeter defense, firewalls, EDR with minimal insider threat investment, rationalizes as 'external threats are bigger risk'

followups.text: How did you determine this allocation was appropriate for your actual risk profile?
Have you measured whether your detection capabilities are balanced - meaning you're equally likely to detect an insider threat as an external attack?

items.text: Describe your security monitoring approach. When an alert fires, what factors determine investigation priority - and in practice, how quickly do internal user alerts get investigated compared to external threat indicators?

scoring_guidance.green: Equal priority for internal and external alerts, can provide examples of prompt insider threat investigations, metrics show balanced response times
scoring_guidance.yellow: Stated policy of equal priority but acknowledges practical delays for internal alerts, limited tracking of response time differences
scoring_guidance.red: External alerts clearly prioritized, internal user alerts backlogged or require additional approval before investigation, 'we trust our employees' attitude

followups.text: Give me a recent example where you had both an internal user doing something unusual and an external threat indicator on the same day - which got investigated first and why?
What's your mean time to detection for insider threats versus external attacks? Do you even track this separately?

subsections.title: Access Controls and Insider Risk Management

items.text: How do you manage privileged access in your environment? Walk me through what happens when someone needs elevated permissions and how often you review who has access to what.

scoring_guidance.green: Formal PAM solution with approval workflows, just-in-time access, quarterly access reviews with documented findings and remediation
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some privileged access controls but informal processes, semi-annual reviews with limited follow-through on findings
scoring_guidance.red: Broad standing privileges for administrators and power users, annual or ad-hoc access reviews, 'we trust our people' approach to internal access

followups.text: When was the last time your access review uncovered someone with inappropriate access - and what did you do about it?
Do you monitor how privileged users actually use their access - session recording, command logging, unusual access patterns?

items.text: Tell me about your approach to vendor and partner security. How do you treat access from trusted business partners versus access from untrusted sources?

scoring_guidance.green: Formal vendor risk program with security assessments, network segmentation for vendor access, ongoing monitoring, treats vendors as external with zero-trust principles
scoring_guidance.yellow: Basic vendor security requirements during onboarding but minimal ongoing oversight, some network separation
scoring_guidance.red: Vendors and partners treated as extensions of organization with trusted access, minimal security oversight beyond contracts, 'they're our partners' attitude

followups.text: Walk me through your most recent vendor security incident or concern - how did you discover it and respond?
Can you show me network segmentation that isolates vendor access from your core systems?

items.text: When you describe your organization's security posture to leadership or external stakeholders, what narrative or story do you tell? Who are the 'good guys' and 'bad guys' in your security story?

scoring_guidance.green: Nuanced narrative acknowledging both external threats and internal vulnerabilities, discusses security as risk management across all vectors
scoring_guidance.yellow: Primarily external threat narrative but can discuss internal factors when asked directly
scoring_guidance.red: Clear good vs. evil narrative with organization defending against external criminals/nation-states, employees and insiders portrayed as needing protection rather than potential sources of risk

followups.text: How comfortable are your executives and employees with acknowledging that insider threats are a real risk in your organization?
Have you ever had pushback when trying to implement insider threat monitoring or controls - what concerns were raised?

items.text: Describe your security awareness training content. What scenarios and examples do you use - and how much emphasizes external threats versus internal responsibilities and insider risk awareness?

scoring_guidance.green: 40%+ of training addresses insider scenarios, social engineering of employees, internal security responsibilities, emphasizes everyone as potential vulnerability
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some insider content (20-40%) but majority focuses on external threats, phishing from outsiders, malware protection
scoring_guidance.red: Training almost entirely focused on external threats, hackers, viruses with minimal content on insider risks or internal security responsibilities

followups.text: Show me an example training module - what's the narrative and who's portrayed as the threat?
Do you conduct phishing simulations that include insider impersonation scenarios, or only external attacker simulations?

subsections.title: Probing for Red Flags
subsections.description: Unconscious shadow projection indicators that increase vulnerability regardless of stated policies

items.label: "We trust our employees - we need to protect them from external hackers, not monitor them..."
"Our biggest threats are sophisticated nation-state actors and organized crime - insider threats aren't really relevant to us..."
"Our vendors and partners are trusted - we don't need to monitor them like external threats..."
Language patterns consistently describe attackers with militaristic or demonizing terms (evil hackers, cyber criminals, advanced adversaries) while using familial or protective language for employees
"We've never had an insider threat incident, so we focus our resources on the real threats from outside..."
Post-incident communications emphasize attacker sophistication while minimizing or omitting discussion of internal control failures
"Employee monitoring would damage trust and culture - we're not that kind of organization..."

solutions.title: Insider Threat Analytics Platform
solutions.description: Deploy user behavior analytics (UBA) tools that monitor employee access patterns, data movement, and system usage for anomalies
solutions.implementation: Implement automated alerts for unusual access times, large data downloads, access to sensitive systems by users without business need, and attempts to access systems outside normal job functions. Baseline normal behavior over 30-60 days, then enable alerting with tiered response workflows.
solutions.technical_controls: UBA platform (Exabeam, Splunk UBA, Microsoft Sentinel UEBA), SIEM integration, data loss prevention correlation, privileged access monitoring
solutions.roi: 280% average within 18 months through early detection of insider threats and reduced dwell time
solutions.timeline: 60-90 days for deployment and baseline establishment

solutions.title: Privileged Access Management (PAM) with Behavioral Monitoring
solutions.description: Implement comprehensive PAM solutions requiring approval workflows for elevated access with session recording for administrative activities
solutions.implementation: Deploy PAM platform with just-in-time access provisioning to minimize standing privileges. Implement session recording for all privileged access. Establish approval workflows with business justification requirements. Automatically de-provision access based on role changes. Maintain detailed audit logs with regular review cycles.
solutions.technical_controls: CyberArk, BeyondTrust, Delinea PAM platforms, session recording, command logging, integration with SIEM for correlation
solutions.roi: 350% average within 12 months through reduced privilege abuse and improved compliance

solutions.title: Vendor Risk Management Program with Ongoing Monitoring
solutions.description: Establish formal vendor security assessment processes with ongoing monitoring of vendor access to organizational systems
solutions.implementation: Implement security questionnaires and penetration testing requirements for critical vendors. Deploy continuous security monitoring of vendor access. Conduct regular security reviews (quarterly for critical vendors). Establish incident notification requirements. Implement network segmentation for vendor connections with micro-segmentation for high-risk access.
solutions.technical_controls: Third-party risk management platform, network segmentation, vendor access monitoring, privileged access management for vendor connections
solutions.roi: 240% average within 18 months through prevention of supply chain compromises

solutions.title: Balanced Security Awareness Training Program
solutions.description: Develop security training that addresses insider threats, internal responsibilities, and social engineering targeting employees with equal emphasis to external threats
solutions.implementation: Restructure training curriculum to allocate 40%+ content to insider risk scenarios. Deploy targeted phishing simulations including insider impersonation scenarios (fake executive emails, fake IT support, fake vendor requests). Provide personalized training based on simulation results. Include executive-level awareness of CEO fraud and business email compromise. Track improvement metrics and adjust training based on results.
solutions.technical_controls: Phishing simulation platform with insider scenarios, learning management system, tracking and analytics, scenario-based training modules
solutions.roi: 310% average within 12 months through reduced social engineering success rates
solutions.timeline: 30 days to restructure curriculum, ongoing delivery

solutions.title: Integrated Threat Intelligence Program
solutions.description: Implement threat intelligence programs that include insider threat indicators, social engineering campaigns, and supply chain risk intelligence alongside external threat feeds
solutions.implementation: Subscribe to insider threat intelligence feeds (industry-specific employee risk indicators, social engineering campaign tracking). Integrate supply chain compromise indicators relevant to organizational vendors. Subscribe to behavioral indicators of potential insider threats (credential misuse patterns, data exfiltration techniques). Integrate all intelligence sources into security monitoring and incident response procedures with contextualized alerting.
solutions.technical_controls: Threat intelligence platform, SIEM integration, insider threat indicator feeds, supply chain risk intelligence, automated indicator ingestion
solutions.roi: 220% average within 18 months through improved threat detection and prevention

solutions.title: Zero Trust Architecture Implementation
solutions.description: Deploy zero trust principles that verify every user and device regardless of location, eliminating implicit trust for insiders
solutions.implementation: Implement continuous verification for all users and devices regardless of network location. Deploy micro-segmentation to limit lateral movement. Require multi-factor authentication for all access (not just external). Continuously monitor all network traffic and user behavior with behavioral baselines. Automatically adjust access permissions based on real-time risk assessment. Eliminate VPN 'trusted network' assumptions.
solutions.technical_controls: Zero trust network access (ZTNA) platform, micro-segmentation tools, continuous authentication systems, risk-based access control, identity-centric security architecture
solutions.roi: 400% average within 24 months through comprehensive risk reduction across internal and external threats

risk_scenarios.title: Malicious Insider Data Exfiltration
risk_scenarios.description: Employees with legitimate access become security risks through financial pressure, ideological motivation, or personal grievances, exploiting organizations' external threat focus to exfiltrate data undetected
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Authorized user abuses legitimate access to download sensitive data, intellectual property, or customer information for personal gain or competitor advantage
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Shadow projection onto external attackers creates blind spot for trusted insiders with authorized access, as monitoring focuses on perimeter rather than privileged user behavior
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Edward Snowden NSA revelations 2013 - agency focus on external surveillance targets while maintaining insufficient internal security oversight enabled massive insider data breach

risk_scenarios.title: Social Engineering via Trusted Insider Impersonation
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers impersonate employees, vendors, or business partners to gain access or manipulate employees into violating security policies, exploiting organizational idealization of insiders
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Phishing or vishing campaigns impersonating internal personnel, using knowledge of organizational structure and relationships to bypass suspicion
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Splitting between 'good employees' and 'bad hackers' makes organizations fail to verify apparent internal communications, assuming internal sources are trustworthy
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Numerous BEC incidents where attackers impersonate executives to authorize fraudulent transfers, succeeding because employees don't question apparent insiders

risk_scenarios.title: Supply Chain Compromise via Trusted Vendor
risk_scenarios.description: Trusted vendors, contractors, or business partners introduce malware, provide unauthorized access, or leak sensitive information while organizations treat partners as safe internal extensions
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Compromised vendor account, malicious vendor employee, or vendor negligence leading to organizational breach via trusted access channels
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizations extend shadow projection's idealization to business relationships, treating vendors as 'part of the family' rather than external entities requiring monitoring
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 breach - HVAC vendor credentials compromised and used to access network, succeeded partly due to trusted vendor access without adequate monitoring

risk_scenarios.title: Privileged Access Abuse During Crisis
risk_scenarios.description: During organizational crisis or incident response, privileged users abuse elevated access while attention focuses on external threat response, exploiting shadow projection amplified by stress
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: System administrator or privileged user exploits crisis distraction and emergency access grants to exfiltrate data, plant backdoors, or conduct sabotage
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Crisis amplifies fight-flight response and shadow projection onto external threats, creating maximum blind spot for insider activities during incident response
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple cases of IT administrators exploiting breach response chaos to establish persistent access or exfiltrate data while organization focuses on external attackers
